messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 60 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: ExKMC: Expanding Explainable ùëò-Means Clustering

Paper Abstract: Abstract Despite the popularity of explainable AI, there is limited work on effective methods for unsupervised learning. We study algorithms for kùëòk-means clustering, focusing on a trade-off between explainability and accuracy. Following prior work, we use a small decision tree to partition a dataset into kùëòk clusters. This enables us to explain each cluster assignment by a short sequence of single-feature thresholds. While larger trees produce more accurate clusterings, they also require more complex explanations. To allow flexibility, we develop a new explainable kùëòk-means clustering algorithm, ExKMC, that takes an additional parameter k‚Ä≤‚â•ksuperscriptùëò‚Ä≤ùëòk^{\prime}\geq k and outputs a decision tree with k‚Ä≤superscriptùëò‚Ä≤k^{\prime} leaves. We use a new surrogate cost to efficiently expand the tree and to label the leaves with one of kùëòk clusters. We prove that as k‚Ä≤superscriptùëò‚Ä≤k^{\prime} increases, the surrogate cost is non-increasing, and hence, we trade explainability for accuracy. Empirically, we validate that ExKMC produces a low cost clustering, outperforming both standard decision tree methods and other algorithms for explainable clustering. Implementation of ExKMC available at https://github.com/navefr/ExKMC.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 60 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 60"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Adaptive sampling for k-means clustering",
        "NP-hardness of Euclidean sum-of-squares clustering",
        "Explainable artificial intelligence (xai): Concepts, taxonomies, opportunities and challenges toward responsible ai",
        "k-means++: The advantages of careful seeding",
        "The hardness of approximation of Euclidean k-means",
        "Scalable fair clustering",
        "Interpretable hierarchical clustering by constructing an unsupervised decision tree",
        "Oblivious dimension reduction for k-means: beyond subspaces and the Johnson-Lindenstrauss lemma",
        "Multidimensional binary search trees used for associative searching",
        "Fair algorithms for clustering",
        "Interpretable clustering via optimal trees",
        "Comparative accuracies of artificial neural networks and discriminant analysis in predicting forest cover types from cartographic variables",
        "Unsupervised feature selection for the k-means clustering problem",
        "Randomized dimensionality reduction for kùëòk-means clustering",
        "Classification and regression trees",
        "A new cell-based clustering method for large, high-dimensional data in data mining applications",
        "Interpretable Clustering Methods",
        "Interpretable clustering via discriminative rectangle mixture model",
        "Python-package for clustering via decision tree construction",
        "Dimensionality reduction for k-means clustering and low rank approximation",
        "The hardness of k-means clustering",
        "Explainable kùëòk-means and kùëòk-medians clustering",
        "Using logical decision trees for clustering",
        "Reliable writer identification in medieval manuscripts through page layout features: The ‚Äúavila‚Äù bible case",
        "Constraints-based explanations of classifications",
        "UCI machine learning repository",
        "The use of multiple measurements in taxonomic problems",
        "Interpretable clustering using unsupervised binary trees",
        "Learning to rank with extremely randomized trees",
        "Inferring biological networks with output kernel trees",
        "R-package for interpretable clustering using unsupervised binary trees",
        "Clustering nominal data using unsupervised binary decision trees: Comparisons with the state of the art methods",
        "Self-organizing feature maps identify proteins critical to learning in a mouse model of down syndrome",
        "Coresets for clustering with fairness constraints",
        "Simultaneous learning of trees and representations for extreme classification and density estimation",
        "A probabilistic analysis of the rocchio algorithm with tfidf for text categorization",
        "A local search approximation algorithm for k-means clustering",
        "From clustering to cluster explanations via neural networks",
        "Fair k-center clustering for data summarization",
        "Learning multiple layers of features from tiny images",
        "Gradient-based learning applied to document recognition",
        "The mythos of model interpretability",
        "Clustering via decision tree construction",
        "Understanding variable importances in forests of randomized trees",
        "A unified approach to interpreting model predictions",
        "(individual) fairness for kùëòk-clustering",
        "Performance of Johnson-Lindenstrauss transform for k-means and k-medians clustering",
        "A morphological database for colombian anuran species from conservation-priority ecosystems",
        "Interpretable Machine Learning",
        "Interpretable machine learning: definitions, methods, and applications",
        "The effectiveness of Lloyd-type methods for the k-means problem",
        "Mixtures of rectangles: Interpretable soft clustering",
        "Global multi-output decision trees for interaction prediction",
        "Density estimation trees",
        "Why should I trust you?: Explaining the predictions of any classifier",
        "Stop explaining black box machine learning models for high stakes decisions and use interpretable models instead",
        "Balancing the tradeoff between clustering value and interpretability",
        "Fair coresets and streaming algorithms for fair k-means",
        "Classifying pairs with trees for supervised biological network inference",
        "A novel unsupervised classification approach for network anomaly detection by k-means clustering and id3 decision tree learning methods"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 60 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in ExKMC: Expanding Explainable ùëò-Means Clustering, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
